item.title: A dispute over the Federal Reserve’s renovation of its headquarters could provide the pretext to attempt the removal of Fed chief Jerome Powell over interest-rate disagreements
item.description: A dispute over the Federal Reserve’s renovation of its headquarters could provide the pretext to attempt the removal of Fed chief Jerome Powell over interest-rate disagreements.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Latest Tariff Threats Could Delay Rate Cuts, Chicago Fed’s Goolsbee Says
item.description: New tariffs unveiled by President Trump have further muddied the inflation outlook, Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee said, making it more difficult for him to support the rate cuts that the president has pressed for.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Nuclear power exemplifies how revamping dated and onerous rules could kick-start investment and innovation, writes the WSJ’s Greg Ip
item.description: Nuclear power exemplifies how revamping dated and onerous rules could kick-start investment and innovation.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Canada Unemployment Rate Slips to 6.9% in June
item.description: A surprise surge in hiring helped pull Canada’s unemployment rate down for the first time since January, a signal of resilience despite the stresses and uncertainty brought on by the Trump administration’s hostile approach to global trade.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: U.S. Inflation Data in Focus
item.description: Investors will focus on U.S. inflation data for June as they look to judge whether the Federal Reserve is likely to cut interest rates any time soon.
item.dc:creator: Dow Jones Newswires Staff

item.title: Businesses hoping for clarity on where Trump tariffs land will likely have to wait a bit longer. For now, here’s where things stand.
item.description: Many countries are set to face higher tariffs on Aug. 1, after months of delay.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: ECB’s Bar for Another Rate Cut Is High, Schnabel Says
item.description: The European Central Bank should refrain from lowering interest rates again after eurozone inflation hit the 2% target in June, rate setter Isabel Schnabel said.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.K. Economy Unexpectedly Slumps to Second Straight Month of Contraction
item.description: The economy contracted in May, a sharp reversal in fortune that makes it more likely the BOE will cut its key interest rate soon.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who newly filed for unemployment benefits declined last week, the Labor Department said, although the report suggested that the size of the unemployed population continued to grow in June.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.K. Home Buyer Demand Turns Positive for First Time Since December
item.description: New buyer inquiries rose 3% in the month, from May’s minus 22%, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: Bank of Korea Holds Rates as Growth Concerns Ebb
item.description: South Korea’s central bank kept interest rates steady in a widely expected move, amid easing concerns over the country’s economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: A brewing debate inside the Federal Reserve over how to address risks posed by President Trump’s tariffs threatens to end a period of relative unity
item.description: Fed Chair Jerome Powell has sketched out new conditions that could trigger rate cuts by summer’s end, but inflation remains a big question.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Minutes from the Fed’s June policy meeting tease at a looming split over whether and when officials will resume rate cuts
item.description: Minutes from the Fed’s June policy meeting tease at a looming split over whether and when officials will resume rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Without Remedy, Countries With Aging Populations Are Set for Weaker Income Growth, Says OECD
item.description: Incomes in rich countries are going to grow much more slowly as populations age unless more women, older people and migrants can be persuaded to work, the OECD said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: President Trump decided to delay the implementation of his so-called reciprocal tariffs to Aug. 1 after advisers including Treasury’s Scott Bessent lobbied for more time to cut deals
item.description: The president also decided to send out letters as a way to keep the pressure up.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: Copper prices surged and the Dow industrials slipped after President Trump announced a large tariff on imports of the metal
item.description: Broader market is little moved by the president’s tough talk on trade.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Osipovich

item.title: Japan Determined to Strike Fair Trade Deal With U.S.
item.description: Japan will keep trying to strike a trade deal with the U.S. that benefits both sides, said Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and his ministers.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Tariff Uncertainty Likely to Weigh on Global Growth Even After Extended Talks
item.description: The extension means that clarity will not come this week—as many had hoped—but it also allows time to negotiate lower tariffs than those currently on pause.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: German Exports Fall Again as Tariffs Drag on Economy
item.description: Exports declined for a second straight month in May in response to higher U.S. tariffs as Europe’s largest economy looks set for another year of little or no growth.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Heard on the Street: The number of first-time home buyers is dwindling, and they are handing a win to landlords
item.description: America’s renter population has hit a record because fewer people can afford to get on the housing ladder.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Mortgage rates holding stubbornly above 6.6% leave many people stuck with higher monthly costs and no path to refinance
item.description: Mortgage rates holding stubbornly above 6.6% leave many people stuck with higher monthly costs and no path to refinance
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: U.S. job growth looked solid in June, but the headline number hides a stark reality: Many private employers aren’t hiring anymore.
item.description: The U.S. economy added 147,000 jobs in June, but nearly half were in government.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber

item.title: Food Prices Rose in June, Driven by Meat, Vegetable-Oil Increases
item.description: Food prices rose in June as higher meat, vegetable-oil and dairy prices offset lower cereal and sugar prices, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the U.N. said.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Hoppe

item.title: U.S. job growth appears strong on the surface, but the underlying pace has been slowing
item.description: Even if Thursday’s jobs report comes in strong, a look behind the headline number tells a different story.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Meanwhile, Bank of England Gov. Bailey says that the ‘direction of interest rates continues to be downwards’
item.description: The central bank’s key interest rate is below the level at which it neither stimulates nor restricts growth, while underlying inflation is set to rise slowly, Gov. Kazuo Ueda said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Germany’s Jobless Rate Holds Steady Despite Signs of Labor-Market Weakness
item.description: The unemployment rate was 6.3% in June for a fourth consecutive month, but signs of a loosening labor market remain as economic uncertainty around trade and geopolitics persists.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Extreme Poverty Becoming More Concentrated in Conflict Countries, Warns World Bank
item.description: The 39 economies classified as facing conflict or instability are set to be home to 60% of those who live in extreme poverty by 2030.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: After the New York City primaries, look to Texas and other red states for lessons on how to make housing markets work, @greg_ip writes
item.description: Austin, Texas, and other red-state cities have set an example for how to make housing markets work.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: U.S. New Home Sales Slump as High Mortgage Rates Persist
item.description: Sales of new homes fell 13.7% to 623,000 in May amid continued concerns over high mortgage costs.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Homeowners who bought around the peak of the market are increasingly finding they owe more on their mortgages than their properties are worth
item.description: Some who bought around the market peak in pandemic boomtowns owe more on their mortgages than their homes are worth.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Stamm

item.title: The Conference Board’s June consumer-confidence index fell to 93, from 98.4 in May, surprising analysts
item.description: U.S. consumer confidence slipped in June, reversing an improvement in May, according to the Conference Board.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.K. Consumer Sentiment Edges Up Again Despite Global Turbulence
item.description: The uptick was likely fuelled by easing price inflation and a cut to interest rates in May.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: It’s a bad time to be a job seeker—especially if you are young
item.description: Slow hiring is especially daunting for those just starting out. “Right now, I’m pretending employment doesn’t exist,” says a recent college graduate.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: Consumers are making spending decisions in the fog of trade war, uncertain about whether higher prices are the result of tariffs, inflation of companies’ push for more profits
item.description: Consumers are making spending decisions in a haze of uncertainty about whether higher prices are the result of tariffs, inflation or companies’ push for more profits.
item.dc:creator: Joe Pinsker

item.title: The University of Michigan said Friday its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May was 50.8, down about 3% from a final reading of 52.2 in April
item.description: The University of Michigan’s closely watched consumer-sentiment index was 50.8 in preliminary numbers for May.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos
